text: I really wouldn’t. You can see who’s doing media as a preen in the mirror, and who’s slogging round hard when they don’t really have to. He’s visibly and obviously the latter.
author: wallaceme

text: Put it this way, almost no-one else on any side - including many for whom it is even more their job than him - do far less.
author: wallaceme

text: It’s a very stark contrast.
author: wallaceme

text: More relentless and dedicated campaigners undoubtedly welcome and needed.
author: wallaceme

text: Meanwhile, @RoryStewartUK has headed straight from the East Surrey AGM to #Newsnight. Whether you agree with him or not, he cannot be accused of being lazy!
author: wallaceme

text: I can understand that. But there doesn’t seem to be any basis for actually doing so in the rules, which is surely a bit of an issue.
author: wallaceme

text: I’m told @SamGyimah’s subsequent Q&A - including robust responses to critics - is going down well overall in the room.
author: wallaceme

text: Definite win for @SamGyimah - at least in the short term. Motion killed, vote avoided. But my sources in the room reckon he’d have won a vote anyway. Is it better in the long run to face and defeat it, or for it to be ruled out in procedural grounds?
author: wallaceme

text: The basis for this seems to be the (very dubious) reading of the rules which @ConHome recently reported that CCHQ was pushing out:
author: wallaceme

text: The Association chairman has refused to accept the proposed motion of no confidence in @SamGyimah, and ruled it out of order. Backed by the South East Regional Chairman. Controversial call - some applause, some booing, one man shouts that the chairman is a “coward”.
author: wallaceme

text: The first critical speaker has just expressed their concern about @SamGyimah’s position on Brexit, and is proposing a motion of No Confidence (it’s not on the main agenda, which was issued some weeks ago).
author: wallaceme

text: This surprised me too but apparently they always have a guest speaker to encourage people to come to their AGM. A good idea!
author: wallaceme

text: It’s @SamGyimah’s association AGM tonight (at which there’s expected to be an effort to vote on a No Confidence motion). I’m told @RoryStewartUK delivered a speech of warm praise for Sam, which was well-received by the audience. Subsequent speakers also v positive about the MP.
author: wallaceme

text: Boom! #england
author: wallaceme

text: Except it isn’t inaccurate. When the day in question has a major one-off event on it which Corbyn’s internal opponents want him to back, pushing the regular activity instead is a deliberate decision.

text: You're repeating yourself without addressing the fact that discourtesy - casual, indulgent, malicious, in the service of a cause, pointless, provoked, unprovoked, or whatever - is part of free speech. You don't even pursue courtesy yourself, but want others arrested for rudeness?

text: Wonderful news!

text: What "concerted interest in Lincoln"? It's part of my job to cover Conservative candidate selections - bit paranoid to think otherwise. You can read some of the hundreds upon hundreds of selections I have covered here: https://www.conservativehome.com/tag/selections
author: wallaceme

text: Indeed. Persuasion takes time and hard work and isn't perfect but is the only valid way to change minds. Any shortcut like compulsion is self-defeating, always.

text: This is pretty desparate - you're arguing Tory MEPs should have been in the same party group as him for a decade.

text: The prisons are going to burst!
author: wallaceme

text: For the record, I disagree that there's no hate towards trans people. I think there still is a sizeable amount, and violence etc over and above that. I just don't agree that causing offence should be treated as a crime.

text: If I am I will be delighted
author: wallaceme

text: Communicating without basic courtesy *is* part of free speech. You’re discourteous, for example, but it would be both wrong and a waste of police time to treat your poor manners as a crime.
author: wallaceme

text: Indeed.
author: wallaceme

text: I think she'll get into a process of endless delay, the Letwin idea (and constitutional outrage) of part of Parliament doing whatever it wants with Government powers will be pushed through, and the end result would be No Brexit.
author: wallaceme

text: I'm afraid we are long past the point at which unquestioning deference to police decisions was advisable.
author: wallaceme

text: Hmm - police can be resistent to even accepting crime reports in many cases, and even after accepting a report will often put on the back burner, then do desk review but shelve. About choosing priorities.
author: wallaceme

text: Wonder all you like. Sources are confidential, rightly.
author: wallaceme

text: An honourable position, Rob. Fact is, most people would support the idea we all ought to be respectful, polite and considerate towards others - while, as you say, not wanting the police involved if someone chooses not to do so.
author: wallaceme

text: It's dubious as to whether it is the law. And even if it is, the entire history of British policing has involved selecting priorities. Are hurt feelings more important than violent crime? Most people would say no. NB I've managed to respond to you without an insult, maybe try it.
author: wallaceme

text: Are you genuinely responding to concerns about policing of free speech with "well if you shut up you won't have any problems"?
author: wallaceme

text: That doesn't appear to be what she said.
author: wallaceme

text: Happy to read and consider a police/CPS account of their actions - but experience counsels against assuming they always act reasonably with regard to free speech.
author: wallaceme

text: There's literally just been an alleged far right stabbing attack in Surrey, but ok.
author: wallaceme

text: Hi Sue - it's entirely possible she is a very unpleasant lady, I don't know her or have any experience of her. However, violating Twitter policy also isn't a crime or a measure of behaviour meriting police involvement.

text: Agreed
author: wallaceme

text: I hear they’re hiring @MNightShyamalan as writer/director.
author: wallaceme

text: That's not how the British police works. Though Government can and should improve the law if it's insufficiently clear.
author: wallaceme

text: It’s ludicrous to police speech in this way. Odd how the police have insufficient resources when it’s knife crime, but officers to spare to hassle people even to the point of interview about complaints that someone is offended.
author: wallaceme

text: We're always happy to learn more!
author: wallaceme

text: Well, feel free to unfollow. Bye.
author: wallaceme

text: I’m not an MP. And if you read the piece you’ll see that if No Deal was available I would leap at it. Indeed if I’m wrong and it still is, I will be delighted. I respect those fellow Leavers who disagree with me - most, unlike you, have the courtesy to do likewise.
author: wallaceme

text: Nope, Brexiteers who hold a different position to you in good faith.
author: wallaceme

text: Thanks - likewise, respect your position but don’t happen to wholly share it. Most important of all that we keep opposing the EU.
author: wallaceme

text: I’ve already answered you. Suggest you read my answer.
author: wallaceme

text: Always nice to be lectured on bravery by *checks notes* ah yes, someone who won't even put their name and face to their tweets. TTFN.
author: wallaceme

text: No Deal is better than a bad deal. A bad deal is better than no Brexit, and still offers the opportunity of a better deal or No Deal.

author: wallaceme

text: Inadvertently that’s the effect however. This is why Remainers are cheering the sight of Leavers making this mistake. I respect your position, it’s honourably held, but I disagree with it.
author: wallaceme

text: I agree the referendum was the crucial difference and they won’t give another. That’s why letting g them trap us into Remain would be a bad mistake
author: wallaceme

text: It was obvious because Parliamentary sovereignty exists. Yes it was treaty based, and still is.

text: Thank you. Not ideal but necessary to fight on.
author: wallaceme

author: wallaceme

text: No. No. NO! A stottie is from Tyneside not Yorkshire. Up with this I will not put. #sacrilege
author: wallaceme

text: You might want to get a bit better at using Twitter, Kevin.
author: wallaceme

text: Even before Lisbon it was obvious we are allowed to leave the EU. Hence UKIP and many of us other Leavers existed before Lisbon (and opposed the treaty’s introduction).
author: wallaceme

text: I have done, thanks.
author: wallaceme

text: There’s a reason Remainers are delighted to see Leavers voting it down.
author: wallaceme

text: To answer your questions, no and no. Full explanation of my views here:
author: wallaceme

text: I’m well aware Leave won and it was a clear choice - I campaigned for it for years, including day and night during the referendum. As per my piece, I continue to fight for proper Brexit - accepting Remain doesn’t serve that.
author: wallaceme

text: Fine by me to answer criticism of my ideas. You sadly prefer ranting to criticism. And the point still stands, if you call others cowardly who put their name to their views, while you hide away, expect to be mocked a bit.
author: wallaceme

text: If we know anything it’s that the House authorities cherrypick the rules to suit on any given day. Don’t be surprised to see it come back once more.
author: wallaceme

text: Parliament is sovereign, and many treaties have been left by many countries. Most obviously, EU membership is treaty-based and we both agree you can leave that.
author: wallaceme

text: I respect your position, but disagree. To use your analogy, the balance pole has been snatched from us, the lights are off, it’s windy and some other bugger has just cut the rope.
author: wallaceme

text: In fairness I’ve heard Man is lovely!
author: wallaceme

text: I’ve been told it’s impossible to Leave before, yet the more we fight and fight smart, the closer we get. Even our situation now was “impossible” only a decade ago. Opt for Remain however and we set back years.
author: wallaceme

text: Always nice to be called cowardly by someone bravely, er, tweeting from a pseudonym without even their own picture to their opinions.
author: wallaceme

text: I appreciate and respect the view, these are tight calls. On counterpoint I’d suggest thinking we can then revert to Remaining and start fighting from scratch is perhaps optimistic on these grounds.
author: wallaceme

text: I respect your position but disagree. Ending up opting for Remain is a far worse and more permanent outcome.
author: wallaceme

text: Thank you
author: wallaceme

text: Totally appreciate the reasonable concern. Neither option is a great one - but Parliament remains sovereign, and, of course, opting for Remain involves trusting the EU...
author: wallaceme

text: Only some rules, only when it suits them, and only in one direction. Hence the bias and hypocrisy.
author: wallaceme

text: Thank you for at least managing a somewhat more civil comment than your previous insults. However, you remain mistaken. If I “knew it” to be any different, I’d say so - I’ve always said what I think, on the basis of heart and head. Sadly you’re relying on the former alone.
author: wallaceme

text: I appreciate the reply and respect your position but it’s a severe mistake. Remain are celebrating Leavers voting the deal down. There is a reason for that.
author: wallaceme

text: If I thought it was available I would jump at the chance.
author: wallaceme

text: Respectfully disagree - glorious defeat is defeat. Fighting on for longer, even harder, but getting the actual goal is best. I want our country to be free.
author: wallaceme

text: I’m not sure there’s any evidence you have...
author: wallaceme

text: Agree on the final point, disagree on the political realities of the situation. Remain would *love* is to opt for Remaining - then they will not let us even get a shot at leaving again. Look at them cheering this error and wonder why.
author: wallaceme

text: Factually correct that’s the current legal position, factually incorrect to claim nothing has changed. Respect your position but I disagree with your opinion.
author: wallaceme

text: Thanks
author: wallaceme

text: Not a reasonable basis in which to discuss. If I noted that Remain are delighted about your attitude and sought to imply you were a secret Remainer it would be ridiculous - yet you do exactly this in response.
author: wallaceme

text: I’ve read it, and many other pieces of his. He’s a great man but we disagree about the political situation.
author: wallaceme

text: Agreed. Sadly they didn’t and the vote was failed.
author: wallaceme

text: That is the question, and I respect those finding the opposite answer, but it’s a severe mistake which would see us kept in the EU permanently.
author: wallaceme

text: Agreed. Sadly I didn’t get to go to the pub on referendum night, I campaigned from 4am til polls closed, then worked from 10pm til 3pm the next day...
author: wallaceme

text: Except any decision is based on a judgement of the likely and the possible, matched up to the desirable and the undesirable. Just saying it’s cowardly to do anything else while ending up Remaining is worse than pointless.
author: wallaceme

text: Thanks, John.
author: wallaceme

text: Not sure what the evidence is that Theresa May won’t do things that are disastrous for her party!
author: wallaceme

text: Like I say May’s Deal is a bad Deal, with much more fighting to do to secure Brexit - my answer was simply to the incorrect claim the UK cannot leave it.
author: wallaceme

text: I’m a supporter of Leave, thanks. You’re supporting Remain now, like it or not.
author: wallaceme

text: Thanks
author: wallaceme

text: Please read the piece, Mark. a) is rather be out with No Deal too, but I think it isn’t available, b) I don’t view May’s deal as an acceptable end goal, but a better route to proper Brexit than Remaining would be.
author: wallaceme

text: If so, and I’m wrong, then I will be delighted. But I don’t think that’s the case with a Parliament and Speaker willing to bend or break anything and everything to get what they want.
author: wallaceme

text: Sympathise with the argument, but there’s a reason Remain are voting down the deal - they are trapping the UK into Remaining...
author: wallaceme

text: Thanks for the reasoned and polite reply, Kevin - I respect your position, too. Indeed it’s a close call and I’ve agonised over both, but I simply think they will not allow another go at leaving if we Remain.
author: wallaceme

text: I appreciate the argument, and have a lot of sympathy with it, but the effect of what you’re suggesting is accepting to a Remain because it becomes the default offered by a Remain Parliament. I’m a Leaver, I think Remain would be the worst outcome.
author: wallaceme

text: Thanks, Rob. Not easy, not palatable, but necessary, I fear.
author: wallaceme

text: Hi Margaret - you don’t seem to have an answer for why he applies conflicting principles at different times, but both in service of the same partisan opinion?
author: wallaceme

text: It wouldn’t, but I like the vivid analogy.
author: wallaceme

text: Wish it or not, leaping to decide its conspiracy motivated by bad faith rather than honestly held opinion is rather unkind. It also renders debate and discussion pointless.
author: wallaceme

text: Of course I can be wrong. So can your other longstanding anti-EU ppl, whose decision is different in part due to different (honourable but mistaken) analysis, in part due to hope trumping experience, in part due to some people touting stuff that feels good but isn’t true, sadly
author: wallaceme

text: I'm being honest - preferable to deceitful spin to "sell", one would hope.
author: wallaceme

text: Absolutely, disagreement and debate is a very healthy thing.
author: wallaceme

text: Quite. We give as good as we get and debate respectfully but energetically. Otherwise we wouldn't keep agreeing to go on air together!
author: wallaceme

text: Thanks, Harry. If they were honourable people, who kept promises and abided by the rules, things would be different. But they aren't.
author: wallaceme

text: As per my piece, we all fight on. We might differ - not for the first time - about the best route to the outcome we want. But we share an outcome. And whatever happens next - Remain, No Deal (), a bad deal etc - we’ll need to fight on, and together.
author: wallaceme

text: Seriously!
author: wallaceme

text: I confess I didn’t expect you to agree, old friend. As I’ve written, the deal is indeed not good, and only properly leaving the EU is in fact good. Remain is even worse than both. I know you don’t, but some of your former colleagues fetishise glorious defeat too much.
author: wallaceme

text: I can understand the anger and frustration. Unfortunately when some people claim actually the choice hasn’t changed, it’s inevitable some of that will be focused on people noting that it has rather than those responsible for doing it. Professional hazard!
author: wallaceme

text: Er, a) that’s not what I said, b) the third vote isn’t the topic, c) I don’t have constituents because d) I’m not an MP which is why e) I don’t have a vote on it. Otherwise, you’re spot on, top marks.
author: wallaceme

text: Again, that’s your right - thought I’d suggest doing exactly what the EU and the Remainers want might not be the best strategy - but it’s your call. Personally I won’t support the UK staying in the EU.
author: wallaceme

text: I respect your different view, and don’t question its motivation. You’d do better to try the same in return - I can disagree with you without being a “coward”, and give my reasons for doing so.

author: wallaceme

text: Not a lot on!

author: wallaceme

author: wallaceme

text: If it turns out I’m wrong, I promise there will be nobody more delighted than me.
author: wallaceme

author: wallaceme

text: Maybe if you keep hearing it there is a reason for that. I haven’t settled for anything, my view is this is the route by which fighting on gets us to full Brexit. And no, a bad Brexit deal is not worse than Remain.
author: wallaceme

text: Double agree.
author: wallaceme

text: Perhaps, though I don’t think it’s quite that settled yet. If so I’ll continue to press for Brexit as soon and as fully as possible.
author: wallaceme

text: Precise analysis of my position. If I’m wrong, I will be more delighted than anyone to discover it.
author: wallaceme

text: No, a lifelong Brexiteer who disagrees with you about how to deliver it. Under my own name, with my face put to my opinions, rather than criticising others as “cowards” from behind hashtag warrior anonymity.

text: Resentfully swallowing May’s Deal might be a better description.
author: wallaceme

text: I respect your position but I’d caution that it’s a mistake - opting to Remain is exactly what Remainers want you to do. Once done, they will use it as the perfect opportunity to ensure we never even get a chance to leave again.
author: wallaceme

text: Not sure what this has to do with the above thread. But I know Bill, thanks, he’s a very good man.
author: wallaceme

text: Not sure which bit of what I’ve written communicates respect for the Government!
author: wallaceme

text: Thank you for the polite and reasoned disagreement, it’s appreciated. Fwiw as I write above, I am fighting for the goal - I’m choosing the route I believe will get us there.
author: wallaceme

text: I respect your position, and I’m happy to agree to disagree if I can’t persuade you. That’s what I was saying earlier about not suggesting I have some secret EU enthusiasm...

text: It is indeed in law. And the Speaker and a majority of the House are demonstrating themselves willing to bend and break all sorts of rules and conventions to undo that and keep us in.

text: As I say in the piece, of No Deal was available I would opt for it. If I’m wrong and it still is available then nobody will be happier than me. But I don’t think it’s the case. For now, at least.

text: Thank you for taking the time to reply, Kitty. If I’m wrong and No Deal turns out to be available, nobody will be happier than me. Sadly I don’t think it’s the case. At least for now.

text: I respect and like Richard a great deal, and we’re both committed Leavers. I just disagree with his view of what Remain would be like, and I think it would make leaving far harder.

text: Probably best to accuse people of “can’t be bothered” and playing a “game” who haven’t campaigned for Brexit for 20 years. I respect your disagreement, and we both want to leave the EU, prefer to remain civil.

text: As I say in the piece, we’ve reached the disgraceful state where Bercow and others are willing to cherrypick the rules and do whatever they want.

text: There's this weird fantasy that treaties once signed are never left. If that was true, we'd still be signatories to every treaty we've ever signed, and so would everyone else. That is not the case.

text: Some people will be aggrieved about my view - indeed, that's how I feel about us Eurosceptics being forced into such a corner. But ultimately this is the same choice we've faced for 40 years: be pure but lose in a blaze of glory, or fight on to win.
author: wallaceme

text: Loathe it though I do, the choice has been changed - instead of Deal or No Deal, we're forced to choose between Deal or No Brexit. I'd rather fight my way out of a bad deal, from outside the EU, than start the 40-year fight to leave from scratch. https://inews.co.uk/opinion/comment/no-brexit-vote-may-deal/ …
author: wallaceme

text: This seems like a timely moment to mention I'll be reviewing the #SkyPapers tonight with the brilliant @JennyKleeman. Another quiet day, looks like it'll be hard to fill the time.

text: Really interesting to compare @GregClarkMP's association AGM - obvious and major Brexit disagreements, but civil and still supportive - with Grantham and Stamford. Suggests @AndrewCooper__'s theory that Tory grassroots are "extremists" doesn't hold water.

text: About a year ago I said to a Downing Street person that fulfilling Brexit was May’s best chance of having a half-decent Wikipedia page in 100 years’ time. The response was a somewhat huffy: “Well, I think we can aim for more than that.” Their problem is this: they can’t.

text: Here’s the letter from @cllrmhill on behalf of the Grantham&Stamford Assoc calling for @NickBoles to resign, says he has “betrayed” local members. (I’ve redacted a paragraph about why the assoc chairman is currently absent - it relates to very sensitive family circumstances.)
author: wallaceme

text: There’s criticism - fine - and stupid violent crap like this which is at best damaging.
author: wallaceme

text: So an awkward position for the national party - if they did want to keep @nickBoles as a member and taking the Tory whip, it seems the G&S Conservative Association would be very unhappy.
author: wallaceme

text: In an email to Grantham and Stamford Tory members, @cllrmhill - VP of the association and leader of Lincs County Council - says “the honourable course” would be for @NickBoles to resign his seat in Parliament.
author: wallaceme

text: That might or might not be allowed, ultimately a question for @BrandonLewis /leadership/whips, and might or might not be sustainable, but not wholly true to say Boles has quit the Conservative Party as some have reported (understandably given the odd technical situation).
author: wallaceme

text: *Important* point: @NickBoles confirms me he is leaving the Grantham & Stamford Association but hopes to continue as a Conservative member through membership of the national party. Membership was recently centralised but so far ppl are automatically allocated to their local assoc
author: wallaceme

text: Ah the reliable entryist fantasy.

text: Via @TonyRoe here is @NickBoles’s letter to local Conservative members:
author: wallaceme

text:
These pieces chart the story of Boles's falling out with his local association (and vice versa). NB that while Brexit is the spark, the problems are older than that):
- 25th Jan: https://www.conservativehome.com/parliament/2019/01/trouble-in-grantham-boless-association-executive-intends-to-accelerate-deselection-proceedings-against-him.html …
- 4th Feb: https://www.conservativehome.com/parliament/2019/02/grantham-and-stamford-association-chairman-expects-proceedings-against-boles-to-begin-next-week.html …
- 11th Feb
author: wallaceme

text: (Somewhat ironically) the closest example I can think of for @NickBoles quitting the Conservatives locally but hoping to stay as a Conservative nationally is @Tim_Aker who left UKIP as a councillor but carried on sitting as a UKIP MEP.
author: wallaceme

text: Wow - very strange situation in Grantham and Stamford. It seems @NickBoles has quit his local association but hopes to continue to take the Conservative whip in Parliament. Hard to think of any precedents for that.
author: wallaceme

text: a) identifying the problems is a necessary precursor to finding the solutions, b) an article has a topic and a length, can’t do everything in one, c) I think I’ve done quite a lot that demonstrates I’m hardly a meek supporter of the status quo in my party or others’.
author: wallaceme

text: As @thhamilton points out, ‘I’m horrible to my staff because Putin’ is quite a, er, memorable defensive line. Staffers aren’t the meat in your Rocky montage.

text: I am a big fan of parliamentary democracy as a system and Parliament as an institution - and it rests on its occupants and officers ultimately. MPs, Speaker, parties, govt, ministers etc. There are serial underperformers in each category at the moment.

text: (And following on from that is a much more complex question of what/how/If parties can change the way they pick, support, manage and promote candidates and MPs to suit this new age not the old one)

text: NB I don’t think I said either of those things. Brexit has made Parliament matter more again, both internally and as the focus of debate and politics, which is a good thing. My point is rather that a good chunk of its occupants, govt included, need to up their game to meet that.
author: wallaceme

text: The farcical state of Parliament - on all sides - reveals how infantilised our politics has become. I expected a Leave victory to be a huge challenge for many MPs, but they have underperformed even my expectations.
